awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Unified Methodology for Optimizing the Management of Chronic Diseases
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is to create new methodology that enables the integration of operational and disease management decisions for patients with chronic diseases. This project focuses on (1) determining when and how to screen, monitor and treat chronic-disease patients given that each patient's disease progression parameter values are not known, (but learned over time), and (2) improving resource allocation given optimal screening, monitoring and treatment decisions over the patient's lifetime. Through a multidisciplinary collaboration with clinicians and managers, the new methodologies created in this award will first be applied to the management of three chronic diseases: glaucoma, bladder cancer, and hypertension. However, it is anticipated that these methodologies will be applicable to other chronic diseases as well. This work will support graduate, undergraduate, and precollege students with attention to underrepresented students. The results of the project will be widely disseminated to engineering and medical communities through user-friendly tools, conference presentations, and journal publications.

The research team will create a novel modeling framework that combines results in survival analysis with a representation of disease progression and intervention using continuous, partially observable state space models of patients within the population. This will be done by (1) dynamically incorporating each patient's disease history into the parameterization of the stochastic model of disease-state evolution, rather than using static population-wide parameter values, (2) comparing policies that lead to improvements from each patient's perspective, rather than those that are based on using constrained resources to improve the health outcomes of the population, and (3) exploiting structural properties of the state-space disease-evolution models to enhance the computation of optimal solutions to problems that use these models in the unified methodology.

por.por_cntn:
This National Science Foundation Award supported the development of a new decision-support methodology that uses operations research (mathematical modeling) and statistics to integrate operational and disease management decisions of patients with three chronic diseases: glaucoma, hypertension, and bladder cancer. The research developed theoretical foundations for (1) determining how often each patient should be monitored while considering resource availability, (2) investigating when more/less aggressive treatment strategies should be pursued based on the patient’s progression characteristics that are learned dynamically over time and (3) guiding post-treatment follow-up after major medical interventions. While some of the models developed are difficult to solve in practice, we were able to provide conditions under which specific policies are indeed optimal. We also considered properties that make these models tractable.

 

From an educational perspective, this research focused on educating both future engineers and clinicians. This proposal supported (1) the development and implementation of a novel healthcare simulation game that allows pre-college students to gain first exposure to the field of operations research, (2) the active involvement of 11 undergraduate engineering students, 7 graduate students, 2 pre-med students, and one medical fellow in research, (3) the design of two case studies that were used in teaching healthcare operations research to engineering students, and (4) the development of a module to introduce future clinicians to the field of operations research.

 

This research has been presented at both engineering and medical conferences nationally and internationally. In addition, it generated publications in top engineering and clinical journals. It was awarded the Production and Operations Management Society College of Healthcare Operations Management Best Paper Award, the American Urological Association Annual Meeting Best Poster Award, the Lee Lusted Award for Quantitative Methods and Theoretical Developments, the American Academy of Ophthalmology Annual Meeting Best Original Glaucoma Paper Award, and the Sanjay and Panna Mehrotra Research Excellence Award. Education efforts of this grant were recognized by the Willie Hobbs Moore Aspire, Advance, Achieve Mentoring Award, and the MICHR Distinguished Clinical and Translational Research Mentor Award. We also created and implemented a pilot tool to integrate our algorithms into clinical practice.
